item.title: Needed for Paris Climate Talks: Handwarmers, Sleeping Bag, Stamina
item.description: Coral Davenport describes how she prepared to cover the the Paris climate talks.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry are greeted on Monday by Segolene Royal, the French minister for ecology, and President François Hollande of France as they arrive for the United Nations climate change summit outside Paris.

item.title: Hope for Nefertiti’s Tomb, and Egypt’s Economy
item.description: The prospect of discovering the long-sought tomb of Queen Nefertiti would be momentous. It would also help Egypt’s tourism industry, which has plummeted in recent years because of political unrest.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: King Tutankhamen’s tomb in the Valley of the Kings, Egypt. Researchers believe there are hollow chambers behind the walls.

item.title: Haenam Journal: Korean County Achieves Its Goal: Less Birth Control, More Babies
item.description: For three straight years, a farming county has had the highest fertility rate in South Korea, a rare bright spot in a country some doomsayers predicted would become “extinct” in several centuries.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newborn babies at nursing room at a public postnatal care center in Haenam, South Korea.

item.title: Sinosphere: Rise in H.I.V. Among China’s Youth Draws Attention for World AIDS Day
item.description: Sexual transmission accounts for more than 92 percent of all new infections, more in line with international norms, figures show.
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: College students in Liaocheng, Shangdong Province, display health packs including condoms distributed as part of an H.I.V./AIDS awareness campaign.

item.title: High Court Denounces Northern Ireland’s Abortion Law
item.description: The procedure is permitted in some circumstances, but the Belfast High Court said the measure was “incompatible with human rights.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Obama, at Conference, Says U.S. Is Partly to Blame for Climate Change
item.description: “The United States of America not only recognizes our role in creating this problem, we embrace our responsibility to do something about it,” the president said on Monday.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China held a bilateral meeting ahead of the United Nations climate change conference in Le Bourget, near Paris, on Monday.

item.title: North Korean Missile Test Was Unsuccessful, South Says
item.description: No rocket trajectory was detected, and what appeared to be debris from a submarine-launched ballistic missile was later seen floating on the surface of the sea, a lawmaker from the South said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, in Kangwon Province this month.

item.title: Two-Thirds of Americans Want U.S. to Join Climate Change Pact
item.description: The stark partisan divide on environmental policy will still make it difficult for President Obama and his successors to put in place energy and climate policies.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO
item.media:description: Drought has brought the water level at Lake Oroville in California close to a record low.

item.title: Two Jewish Teenagers Found Guilty of Murdering Palestinian, 16
item.description: Sentencing hearings for the two in the kidnapping and killing of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, who was bludgeoned and burned to death in 2014, will begin in mid-January.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Itineraries: Dip in Tourism After Most Attacks Is Short-Lived, Study Says
item.description: An analysis of the impact of terrorist attacks on travel and tourism suggests that the long-term effect is more muted than after a natural disaster.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: A woman at the Eiffel Tower. Paris is trying to recover from the recent terror attacks that killed 130 people.

item.title: Exchange of Spies With China Is Positive Sign, Taiwan Says
item.description: Taiwan’s officers Chu Kung-hsun and Hsu Chang-kuo were returned in mid-October, and a Chinese spy imprisoned in Taiwan, Li Zhihao, was given early parole.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere: The Findings of China’s Climate Change Report
item.description: The latest report by the Chinese government assesses how climate change has affected and is likely to affect China.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A woman wearing a mask in central Beijing on Monday in the worst recorded smog of the year. Dangerous particulates reached nearly 20 times healthy levels as President Xi Jinping joined other world leaders in Paris for climate change talks.

item.title: Predatory Islamic State Wrings Money From Those It Rules
item.description: The earnings from the militants’ violent collection practices total tens of millions of dollars a month, approaching $1 billion a year, according to some estimates.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG, NICHOLAS KULISH and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: A photo from an Islamic State website showed a member sorting envelopes of zakat, or alms, collected from the rich to be distributed to the poor during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan in Mosul.

item.title: News Analysis: Discord Between Turkey and Russia Is Fueled by Leaders’ Similarities
item.description: Not long ago, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, earned about the warmest accolade possible from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. That was then.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Office, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Presidents Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey last year.

item.title: Yolanda Sonnabend, Designer Who Influenced Choreographer, Dies at 80
item.description: Ms. Sonnabend had a long and successful collaboration with the British choreographer and Royal Ballet director Kenneth MacMillan.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS
item.media:description: Yolanda Sonnabend worked in ballet and opera and had a career as a painter and portraitist.

item.title: White House Letter: A Coalition in Which Some Do More Than Others to Fight ISIS
item.description: President Obama has sought to make clear that the United States is not alone in its fight against the Islamic State, though some members of an often-cited coalition may be doing less than others.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama, traveling Sunday to Paris, has cited the number of nations fighting the Islamic State, though contributions vary.

item.title: France Uses Sweeping Powers to Curb Climate Protests, but Clashes Erupt
item.description: Despite efforts to limit any disruption to a two-week global climate conference in Paris, 174 people were taken into custody when demonstrators fought with the police.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Police officers fought with demonstrators during a protest on Sunday in Paris before a global climate conference there. Protesters were demonstrating to urge the adoption of a strong agreement to curb global warming.

item.title: In Africa, Pope Francis Makes His First Visit to a War Zone
item.description: Pope Francis landed in Bangui, capital of the divided and destitute Central African Republic, in a bid to support efforts at peace and reconciliation.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Pope Francis blessed children while visiting a refugee camp on Sunday in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.

item.title: E.U. Offers Turkey 3 Billion Euros to Stem Migrant Flow
item.description: European Union leaders met with Turkey’s prime minister on Sunday, promising aid and other inducements in exchange for Turkish action to clamp down on asylum seekers.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu of Turkey, who stood in for the Turkish president in Brussels, before a summit meeting with European Union leaders on Sunday.

item.title: Tensions With Russia Add to a Chill in Turkey’s Economy
item.description: Even before Russia imposed sanctions over the downing of a combat jet, an influx of migrants and a loss of export markets hindered Turkey’s economy.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The area outside Resadiye Mosque in Eskisehir, Turkey, is a gathering place for workers waiting to be hired. Lately, Syrian migrants have taken some of these jobs at lower wages.
